awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Last Gasp - Shutting Down Massive Galaxies at z~0.6
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will study distant galaxies in the midst of shutting down their last burst of star formation and metamorphosing from spiral galaxies - like the Milky Way - into round and dead elliptical galaxies. Although this process is common, as most large galaxies are ellipticals while young galaxies are spirals, it is poorly understood. This project will use the detailed properties of newly transformed galaxies in stars and gas to test formation models. The broader impacts will support underrepresented minority students transition to graduate school through bridge programs at Princeton University and the University of Pittsburgh.

This work assesses possible quenching mechanisms using a unique sample of intermediate-redshift massive post-starburst galaxies. These galaxies have recently quenched their major star-forming episode - yet they are sufficiently nearby that multi-wavelength observations can illuminate their detailed, spatially resolved stellar properties and molecular gas reservoirs. By combining the resolved kinematics, distribution of stellar ages, remaining gas content, and visual morphologies of this statistical sample of recently quenched massive galaxies and comparing with the timescales and stochasticity of quenching within the SIMBA cosmological simulations, this project will determine the dominant quenching mechanism(s) driving the transformation of blue star forming, rotating, disk galaxies into red-and-dead, kinematically hot, spheroids. In addition, the team will extend a proven program to broaden and strengthen support of post-baccalaureate students at Princeton and the University of Pittsburgh.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In the Universe today, the most massive galaxies are overwhelmingly ``red and dead.'' That means that with very few exceptions they do not contain any cold gas or ongoing star formation. A major question in galaxy evolution today is to determine what stopped star formation so early in these massive galaxies. We have assembled a large sample of massive galaxies roughly half the age of the universe ago that have very recently stopped a major episode of star formation. That is, they formed more than half of their stars in the past billion years or less. The goal of our project is to investigate how they formed those stars, and what processes stopped the star formation.

To understand this question, we need to take a multi-wavelength approach. WIth the SDSS spectra, we studied the star formation histories of these galaxies to show that they have indeed built up more than half of their current mass in their latest burst of star formation. From optical images, we show that this recent starburst was likely triggered by a recent galaxy merger. Using the sub-millimeter telescope ALMA, we have been measuring the cold gas content of these so-called post-starburst galaxies. The most susprising result of our study is the finding that the youngest galaxies, those only 100-200 Myr since their starburst, generally harbor large resevoirs of cold molecular gas that is not forming stars as we would expect. In contrast galaxies that are 0.5-1 Gyr from their star formation episode are gas poor. We do not know whether we are seeing two different populations, or if some process removes that gas (star formation cannot deplete it in time).

One possible culprit is active galactic nuclei. We have one spectacular source that is spewing molecular gas well beyond the stellar bounds of the galaxy as part of a merger, and this galaxy also harbors an accreting black hole. But we do not yet have a full understanding of the role of black hole accretion in the massive galaxy lifecycle.

The future is bright for post starburst galaxy research. The Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument and the Prime Focus Spectrograph are poised to discover large numbers of post starburst galaxies at higher redshift, which will in turn teach us how these galaxies connect to typical massive galaxies.
